greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows where T(n,k) is the number of reversed integer partitions of n with k distinct differences of any degree.
comment: The differences of a sequence are defined as if the sequence were increasing, so for example the differences of (6,3,1) are (-3,-2).

The zeroth differences of a sequence are the sequence itself, while the k-th differences for k > 0 are the differences of the (k-1)-th differences. The distinct differences of any degree are the union of the k-th differences for all k >= 0. For example, the k-th differences of (1,1,2,4) for k = 0...3 are:
so there are a total of 4 distinct differences of any degree, namely {0,1,2,4}.
link: Gus Wiseman, Sequences counting and ranking integer partitions by the differences of their successive parts.
example: Row n = 8 counts the following partitions:
